top_comment.author: LTrotsky 21st Century

comments.text:
+LTrotsky 21st Century Prior to the collapse, the Canadian banking industry 
had been pushing for less regulations, but not full de-regulation. They 
used the same arguments that had been used successfully in the US but the 
federal government wouldn't budge. Then things fell apart. The impact was a 
fraction of what it was elsewhere, namely the US, and the Canadian banking 
industry changed its tune. While they argued that the regulations in place 
prevented them from making even more money, these same regulations kept 
them alive and making money throughout the crisis. So yes, they know the 
regs and the fed's opposition to changing them saved their asses. With that 
being said, one can't help but wonder when they'll try again. As a citizen 
who has stock in 2 different banks, I hope the regulations stay put. The 
issue isn't the banks making money (they make several billion dollars each 
year) it's the issue of making more. Many American banks don't care if 
their business practices lead to economic disasters as long as they make 
more and more money. I'm glad that our federal government over the last few 
decades has been aware of the potential for abuse (which is exactly what 
happened with American banks) and had steadily changed regulations to 
mitigate such risk. I'm not saying we've got it all figured out, but in 
this one particular area we seem to have gotten our collective shit pretty 
much together.

As for Harper, he has supported the continued regulatory model. Some 
dislike him because he's not flashy or charismatic, rather grey, but that's 
also why the majority of Canadians like him. He just does his job. He is a 
Conservative, but acts more like a progressive. He sees that for Canada to 
thrive and grow, some of the old ideas have to be thrown out and bring in 
some new ones that reflect the changing global economy, like he did just 
recently by signing a free trade agreement with South Korea. S.Korea has 
the 13th (pretty sure) largest economy in the world so trade with them 
would be huge for both nations. Sure, the big 3 American automakers make 
not like it, but protecting them by all means possible is one of those old 
ideas that has to go.
comments.author: Ranni Kaffar

comments.text:
+Ranni Kaffar Except that Canada wasn't unaffected. Capitalism is the 
dominant global paradigm, driving the world economy. Speaking of it in 
purely national terms is to miss the issue. Canadian trade was affected,

absent the bailout those instruments would have wiped out a great deal of

comments.text:
+Gnomefro You can't regulate them in the context of capitalist social 
relations. No capitalist society has yet eliminated fictitious capital 
creation. And, as I suggested, this is one of but not the only source of 
chaos in the capitalist economy - the other is called by bourgeois 
economists "overproduction" but which communists call appropriation.

There are various reasons why fictitious capital creation is inherent to 
capitalism, and why it therefore cannot be eliminated - if you read Marx 
you can discover this. But, in more practical terms, among the main reasons 
it can't be eliminated is because of the control exerted by capitalists - 
by the entire dynamic of capitalist social relations - on the political 
system. Why was Glass-Steagall, a law put into effect during the FDR regime 
to prevent banks speculating with deposits, repealed by the Clinton regime? 
For the reason I just mentioned. The GSA was not a full prophylactic on 
"speculation" or fictitious capital creation, only a partial one in one 
segment of the financial "industry". Even this small preventative could not 
be maintained politically.

Your statement regarding the "failed" economic systems of communist states 
is utterly wrong, and unfortunately simply displays your ignorance of 
historical economic data. Or, perhaps more accurately, your statement is 
merely an uncritical reflection of bourgeois ideology, a reflection which, 
additionally, is a further demonstration of why you cannot get rid of 
fictitious capital creation in capitalism : the conceptions necessary to do 
so do not arise in the minds of people wedded to the capitalist mindset. 
How many times have you heard capitalists say "speculation is necessary" 
and "provides insurance to the markets" - when of course this is the exact 
opposite of the truth (assuming the terms could be defined).
comments.author: LTrotsky 21st Century

comments.text:
+ChristianIce
people should not be giving advice or putting money into things they don't 
fully understand the risks of. there are other risks with bonds. inflation 
isn't really a "risk" as opposed to a "disadvantage," since bonds have 
lower returns compared to many other types investments, and inflation only 
directly affects the buying power of the currency, not the absolute value 
or the return of bond. however, inflation could affect demand for a bond, 
which may indirectly affect the premium or discounts of existing  bonds. 
there are 2 primary risks to owning bonds. default or bankruptcy of the 
bond issuer is always a risk, just like any other stock or loan based 
investment. the most active day-to-day risk and what people are talking 
about as a "bubble" is that any change in interest rates can change the 
market price of bonds by a multiple of their affective duration. if a bond 
has 10 years, and the interest rates increase by 1 percent, the market 
price of a bond will decrease by 10%, which is huge. since the current 
short term interest rates are artificially set to almost 0, there is room 
for large and sudden jumps in the interest rates if the market ever decided 
to ignore the set interest rates. people could lose 1/2 or more of the 
value of their long term bonds or mutual bond funds if  the interest rate 
jumps a few percent. bond funds are more susceptible to this since you can 
never collect on the principle, only sell your shares at market value. 
directly owning bonds can avoid this if you never sell your bond. however, 
your money is stuck with that low interest rate while other people are 
buying new bonds with higher rates. the other huge consequence of a burst 
"bond bubble" is that if the interest rates go up despite the fed 
guidelines, the government will have to follow suit and start paying a lot 
more interest for new issue treasuries. the cost of their annual interest 
payments could start to make up the majority if the annual budget, which is 
crazy. imagine if you made the average american income of 36k and had to 
pay 18k in interest on your loans, and that your loan size keeps going up 
every year, or at least never decreases.

top_comment.text:
*inflating the bubble*

Cenk, you're a complete dumbass.  Just stop talking.

The subprimes were issued BECAUSE the bubble was already too large.  The 
subprimes did not inflate the bubble, it just extended how large the bubble 
could get.

*The new bubble*

Cenk, it is YOU who don't understand what a bubble even is.  A "bubble" is 
an overinflation of the value of something.  Since you do not own anything 
when you are renting a property, there aren't things like equity and other 
comparisons that will drive people to foreclose.  The foreclosures mostly 
didn't happen because people couldn't afford to pay their rent.  Indeed, 
most people actually continued to pay and I would venture to say that over 
half are paying that rent today.

The issue with foreclosures happened when equity plumitted.  People would 
be paying the banks $350K for a house that dropped to under $100K.  THAT'S 
what drove people to abandon their bank agreements.  People understood that 
it simply wasn't worth it.  

*Half of all income to rentals*

lol, Cenk.  Many poorer people will spend over half their money on rent 
alone, that's just the way it is.  To ignore this means to just not 
understand what the poor go through.  It's not a bubble, it's just the 
difference between paying rent and paying a mortgage.  They aren't the same 
thing.  

When someone abandons a rental, the bank just looks for a new person to 
rent the property.  The bank does not have to look for another buyer and 
they don't have to measure against equity.  Rental value is determined by 
the value of taxes and/or mortgages, the values of other homes within the 
city, and the quality of the home (including the area).  Bubbles don't 
exist in rentals because, when you rent out your property, you are 
providing a service, and services do not have bubbles.

Bubbles get attached to things with tangible value such as the actual sale 
of property.  

So, in a nutshell, you don't even know what the hell you're talking about.﻿

comments.text:
It is called "hedging" or "hedging your bets".  As a simplistic example, it 
typically involves something like buying stock in a commodity on the 
assumption that the price will go up after you buy it, and then 
simultaneously, short-selling stock in that same commodity on the 
assumption that the price will go down.  Sometimes it is not quite the same 
commodity or stock or whatever, but is still equivalent to putting money on 
the assumption that things will go the other way. 

As for exactly how they bet "against" something, like with "short-selling", 
is a little complicated.  Ultimately, it comes down to not just 
buying/investing in something, but also *promising* to buy something in the 
future, if that thing is expected to lose value.  In short-selling, I 
"borrow" stock from you at the current price, on the assumption that the 
price will go down, which means I "take" the stock and sell it to the 
market-at-large, while giving you a "lender's fee" and the promise that you 
will get that stock back later.  When the price of that stock goes down, I 
then buy the same amount of that stock from the market-at-large, but now at 
a lower price.  Because the price is now lower, I did not have to use as 
much money to buy it, thus the difference is new revenue, and if that 
revenue is greater than the lending fee I paid you, then the remainder is 
profit. 
You also profit by way of the lender's fee, but doing so means that you did 
not want to otherwise act on the possibility that the stock price would go 
down.
